question: Question_02
statement:
Compute the determinant of the matrix

\[A =  \begin{bmatrix}
1& 1& x& 1\\ 
x& 1& 1& 1\\ 
1 & 1&1 &x \\ 
1&x &1 & 1
\end{bmatrix}\]
sols:
Expanding on the first row gives

\begin{align*}
\det(A) &= \displaystyle (1)\text{det}\left(\begin{bmatrix} 1& 1& 1\\ 
1&1 &x \\ 
x &1 & 1\end{bmatrix}\right) - (1)\text{det}\left(\begin{bmatrix} x& 1& 1\\ 
1&1 &x \\ 
1 &1 & 1\end{bmatrix}\right) \\
&\quad + (1)\text{det}\left(\begin{bmatrix} x& 1& 1\\ 
1&1 &x \\ 
1 &x & 1\end{bmatrix}\right) - (1)\text{det}\left(\begin{bmatrix} x& 1& 1\\ 
1&1 &1 \\ 
1 &x & 1\end{bmatrix}\right)
\end{align*}

Performing one row swap in the first, third and fourth terms (which
changes the sign of the determinant) yields

\begin{align*}
\det(A) &= \displaystyle -(1)\text{det}\left(\begin{bmatrix} x& 1& 1\\ 
1&1 &x \\ 
1 &1 & 1\end{bmatrix}\right) - (1)\text{det}\left(\begin{bmatrix} x& 1& 1\\ 
1&1 &x \\ 
1 &1 & 1\end{bmatrix}\right) \\
&\quad - (x)\text{det}\left(\begin{bmatrix} x& 1& 1\\ 
1&x &1 \\ 
1 &1 & x\end{bmatrix}\right) + (1)\text{det}\left(\begin{bmatrix} x& 1& 1\\ 
1&x &1 \\ 
1 &1 & 1\end{bmatrix}\right)
\end{align*}

Now the first two terms are the same so we combine them to get

\begin{align*}
\det(A) &= \displaystyle -(2)\text{det}\left(\begin{bmatrix} x& 1& 1\\ 
1&1 &x \\ 
1 &1 & 1\end{bmatrix}\right) - (x)\text{det}\left(\begin{bmatrix} x& 1& 1\\ 
1&x &1 \\ 
1 &1 & x\end{bmatrix}\right)  \\
&\quad + (1)\text{det}\left(\begin{bmatrix} x& 1& 1\\ 
1&x &1 \\ 
1 &1 & 1\end{bmatrix}\right)
\end{align*}

The remaining determinants can be calculated by hand to give

\begin{align*}
\det(A) &= (-2)(x + x +1 -(1 + 1 + x^{2})) +(-x)(x^{3}+1+1-(x+x+x)) +(1)(x^{2}+1+1-(x+1+x))\\
&= -2(-x^{2}+2x-1)-(x)(x^{3}-3x+2) + (x^{2}-2x+1)\\
&= -x^{4}+6x^{2}-8x+3
\end{align*}
